UseFiniteElementDeflectionsForFoundation.description:
When this feature is enabled, support structure deflections calculated from the underlying finite element model are used to evaluate the foundation applied loads. The effect of these foundation loads is included when evaluating the turbine dynamic response.

This model is only active for time domain simulations. The foundation applied loads are calculated from the finite element deflections from the previous time step. This means that time step convergence studies may be required to ensure the accuracy of this model.

When this feature is enabled, the support structure node deflection outputs will be based on the finite element model rather than the modal deflections that are normally used. This ensures consistency between the foundation applied loads and the support structure node deflections.
UseFiniteElementDeflectionsForFoundation.markdownDescription:
UseFiniteElementDeflectionsForFoundationLoads: **boolean**

_**Not supported yet**_

_When this feature is enabled, support structure deflections calculated from the underlying finite element model are used to evaluate the foundation applied loads. The effect of these foundation loads is included when evaluating the turbine dynamic response._

_This model is only active for time domain simulations. The foundation applied loads are calculated from the finite element deflections from the previous time step. This means that time step convergence studies may be required to ensure the accuracy of this model._

_When this feature is enabled, the support structure node deflection outputs will be based on the finite element model rather than the modal deflections that are normally used. This ensures consistency between the foundation applied loads and the support structure node deflections._

Optional, Default = `false`

The wake width is constant in the case of there being no downstream variation, but in the case of an inverse square variation, the wake width is applied at the reference length, "Powles L Reference" (the width at other points scaling in proporton to the square root of the distance downstream).
ShadowWidthProportion.markdownDescription:
ShadowWidthProportion: **number**

_The wake width as a proportion of the local obstruction's diameter.  The wake width is constant in the case of there being no downstream variation, but in the case of an inverse square variation, the wake width is applied at the reference length, "Powles L Reference" (the width at other points scaling in proporton to the square root of the distance downstream)._

Default = `0.0`

MaximumDeficit.description: The maximum deficit for use in the empirical Powles equation, expressed as a fraction of the unperturbed flow.
MaximumDeficit.markdownDescription:
MaximumDeficit: **number** (m/s)

_The maximum deficit for use in the empirical Powles equation, expressed as a fraction of the unperturbed flow._

Default = `0.0`

LengthReference.description: The distance downstream of the obstruction that the maximum deficit is applicable for, expressed as a multiple of the obstruction's diameter.
LengthReference.markdownDescription:
LengthReference: **number**

_The distance downstream of the obstruction that the maximum deficit is applicable for, expressed as a multiple of the obstruction's diameter._

Default = `0.0`

If any individual parameter of the TopCrossSection is omitted, then it will be assumed to be the same as in the BaseCrossSection.

@Material.description:
A reference to a material in the tower's material library, using the key of the TowerMaterial in the Tower MaterialsLibrary.

i.e. `MaterialsLibrary.<material-key>`

BaseCrossSection.description: The structural properties at the base of the tower can.
BaseCrossSection.markdownDescription:
BaseCrossSection: **object (TowerCanPropertiesByMaterial)**

_The structural properties at the base of the tower can._

TopCrossSection.description: The structural properties at the top cross-section of the tower can.  If this is not defined, it will be assumed that the cross-section is constant for the entire length.  If any individual parameter of the TopCrossSection is omitted, then it will be assumed to be the same as in the BaseCrossSection.
TopCrossSection.markdownDescription:
TopCrossSection: **object (TowerCanPropertiesByMaterialWhereDifferent)**

_The structural properties at the top cross-section of the tower can.  If this is not defined, it will be assumed that the cross-section is constant for the entire length.  If any individual parameter of the TopCrossSection is omitted, then it will be assumed to be the same as in the BaseCrossSection._

TowerCanModelling.title: TowerCanModelling
TowerCanModelling.description: Parameters controlling the way the can will be modelled by Bladed.
TowerCanModelling.markdownDescription:
### TowerCanModelling

_Parameters controlling the way the can will be modelled by Bladed._

- `MaximumNodeSpacing`: **number** (m)
- `NumberOfIntermediateNodes`: **integer**

or

- `$insert`: **string (URI-reference)**

MaximumNodeSpacing.description: If any two nodes are further spaced apart than this, an additional node or nodes will be added equally spaced between them.  The default is infinity, meaning that no extra nodes will ever be added unless NumberOfIntermediateNodes has been specified.
MaximumNodeSpacing.markdownDescription:
MaximumNodeSpacing: **number** (m)

_If any two nodes are further spaced apart than this, an additional node or nodes will be added equally spaced between them.  The default is infinity, meaning that no extra nodes will ever be added unless NumberOfIntermediateNodes has been specified._

NumberOfIntermediateNodes.description: The number of structural nodes to be added, equally spaced between the top and bottom of the can.  The default is 0, meaning that (unless the MaximumNodeSpacing requires additional nodes to be added) the can will be represented by a single beam.
NumberOfIntermediateNodes.markdownDescription:
NumberOfIntermediateNodes: **integer**

_The number of structural nodes to be added, equally spaced between the top and bottom of the can.  The default is 0, meaning that (unless the MaximumNodeSpacing requires additional nodes to be added) the can will be represented by a single beam._

Default = `0`

Translation.title: Translation
Translation.description: An offset between two components, or the origin - [0,0,0] - and the first component in the Assembly tree.  This will be modelled as completely rigid.
Translation.markdownDescription:
### Translation

_An offset between two components, or the origin - [0,0,0] - and the first component in the Assembly tree.  This will be modelled as completely rigid._

- _`ComponentType`_: **string = `Translation`**
- `X`: **number** (m), _Optional_
- `Y`: **number** (m), _Optional_
- `Z`: **number** (m), _Optional_

or

- `$insert`: **string (URI-reference)**

A type of **Component**

ComponentType.description: Defines the specific type of Component model in use.  For a `Translation` object, this must always be set to a value of `Translation`.
ComponentType.markdownDescription:
ComponentType: **string = `Blade` | `DrivetrainAndNacelle` | `ExternalModuleComponent` | `FixedSpeedActiveDamper` | `Flexibility` | `IndependentPitchHub` | `Lidar` | `LinearPassiveDamper` | `PendulumDamper` | `PitchSystem` | `RigidBodyPointInertia` | `RigidBodySixbySixInertia` | `Rotation` | `Superelement` | `Tower` | `Translation` | `VariableSpeedActiveDamper` | `VariableSpeedGenerator` | `YawSystem`**

_Defines the specific type of Component model in use.  For a `Translation` object, this must always be set to a value of `Translation`._

---

### Translation

_An offset between two components, or the origin - [0,0,0] - and the first component in the Assembly tree.  This will be modelled as completely rigid._

- _`ComponentType`_: **string = `Translation`**
- `X`: **number** (m), _Optional_
- `Y`: **number** (m), _Optional_
- `Z`: **number** (m), _Optional_

or

- `$insert`: **string (URI-reference)**

A type of **Component**

X.description: The translation in the X-direction of the previous component's distal frame of reference.  This will be in the global coordinate system if this is the first component in the Assembly tree.
X.markdownDescription:
X: **number** (m)

_The translation in the X-direction of the previous component's distal frame of reference.  This will be in the global coordinate system if this is the first component in the Assembly tree._

Optional, Default = `0.0`

Y.description: The translation in the Y-direction of the previous component's distal frame of reference.  This will be in the global coordinate system if this is the first component in the Assembly tree.
Y.markdownDescription:
Y: **number** (m)

_The translation in the Y-direction of the previous component's distal frame of reference.  This will be in the global coordinate system if this is the first component in the Assembly tree._

Optional, Default = `0.0`

Z.description: The translation in the Z-direction of the previous component's distal frame of reference.  This will be in the global coordinate system if this is the first component in the Assembly tree.
Z.markdownDescription:
Z: **number** (m)

_The translation in the Z-direction of the previous component's distal frame of reference.  This will be in the global coordinate system if this is the first component in the Assembly tree._

Optional, Default = `0.0`

StructuralMode.title: StructuralMode
StructuralMode.description: An object containing the DampingRatio for a particular structural mode. Used by the support structure to include structural modes and their associated DampingRatios, as well as by the blades to define WholeBladeModeDampingRatios. Users can add any metadata alongside the DampingRatio, such as _Name or _Mode. Bladed will disregard any metadata as long as it is prefixed with an underscore.
StructuralMode.markdownDescription:
### StructuralMode

_An object containing the DampingRatio for a particular structural mode. Used by the support structure to include structural modes and their associated DampingRatios, as well as by the blades to define WholeBladeModeDampingRatios. Users can add any metadata alongside the DampingRatio, such as \_Name or \_Mode. Bladed will disregard any metadata as long as it is prefixed with an underscore._

- `DampingRatio`: **number**, _Optional_

or

- `$insert`: **string (URI-reference)**

DampingRatio.description: The damping ratio on the mode.  This is typically in the order of 0.005.  An underdamped mode can lead to numerical instability in the simulation, whereas overdamped mode can affect the veracity of the results.
DampingRatio.markdownDescription:
DampingRatio: **number**

_The damping ratio on the mode.  This is typically in the order of 0.005.  An underdamped mode can lead to numerical instability in the simulation, whereas overdamped mode can affect the veracity of the results._

Optional

EquilibriumWakeModel.title: EquilibriumWakeModel
EquilibriumWakeModel.description: The equilibrium wake model instantaneously updates the induction in response to changes operating condition.  This represents the steady state solution.  It should not be used in linearisation as it would represent an instantaneous response of the wake, where in reality the response is significantly lagged.  It is also not a good approach for time domain as the lagged wake response is not captured.
EquilibriumWakeModel.markdownDescription:
### EquilibriumWakeModel

_The equilibrium wake model instantaneously updates the induction in response to changes operating condition.  This represents the steady state solution.  It should not be used in linearisation as it would represent an instantaneous response of the wake, where in reality the response is significantly lagged.  It is also not a good approach for time domain as the lagged wake response is not captured._

- _`DynamicWakeType`_: **string = `EquilibriumWakeModel`**
- `AreaAveragingMethod`: **string = `OVER_ANNULUS` | `NONE`**, _Optional_

or

- `$insert`: **string (URI-reference)**

A type of **DynamicWake**

DynamicWakeType.description: Defines the specific type of DynamicWake model in use.  For a `EquilibriumWakeModel` object, this must always be set to a value of `EquilibriumWakeModel`.
DynamicWakeType.markdownDescription:
DynamicWakeType: **string = `EquilibriumWakeModel` | `FreeFlowModel` | `FrozenWakeModel` | `OyeDynamicWake` | `PittAndPetersModel`**

_Defines the specific type of DynamicWake model in use.  For a `EquilibriumWakeModel` object, this must always be set to a value of `EquilibriumWakeModel`._

---

### EquilibriumWakeModel

_The equilibrium wake model instantaneously updates the induction in response to changes operating condition.  This represents the steady state solution.  It should not be used in linearisation as it would represent an instantaneous response of the wake, where in reality the response is significantly lagged.  It is also not a good approach for time domain as the lagged wake response is not captured._

- _`DynamicWakeType`_: **string = `EquilibriumWakeModel`**
- `AreaAveragingMethod`: **string = `OVER_ANNULUS` | `NONE`**, _Optional_

or

- `$insert`: **string (URI-reference)**

A type of **DynamicWake**

FreeFlowModel.title: FreeFlowModel
FreeFlowModel.description: The Free-flow dynamic wake model represents a case where there is no induction, and so no momentum calculation.  The lift, drag and moment polars are used directly.  This could be appropriate to use in e.g. parked or idling.  This option might be removed in a future re-design of the aerodynamic settings.
FreeFlowModel.markdownDescription:
### FreeFlowModel

_The Free-flow dynamic wake model represents a case where there is no induction, and so no momentum calculation.  The lift, drag and moment polars are used directly.  This could be appropriate to use in e.g. parked or idling.  This option might be removed in a future re-design of the aerodynamic settings._

- _`DynamicWakeType`_: **string = `FreeFlowModel`**
- `AreaAveragingMethod`: **string = `OVER_ANNULUS` | `NONE`**, _Optional_

or

- `$insert`: **string (URI-reference)**

A type of **DynamicWake**

DynamicWakeType.description: Defines the specific type of DynamicWake model in use.  For a `FreeFlowModel` object, this must always be set to a value of `FreeFlowModel`.
DynamicWakeType.markdownDescription:
DynamicWakeType: **string = `EquilibriumWakeModel` | `FreeFlowModel` | `FrozenWakeModel` | `OyeDynamicWake` | `PittAndPetersModel`**

_Defines the specific type of DynamicWake model in use.  For a `FreeFlowModel` object, this must always be set to a value of `FreeFlowModel`._

---

### FreeFlowModel

_The Free-flow dynamic wake model represents a case where there is no induction, and so no momentum calculation.  The lift, drag and moment polars are used directly.  This could be appropriate to use in e.g. parked or idling.  This option might be removed in a future re-design of the aerodynamic settings._

- _`DynamicWakeType`_: **string = `FreeFlowModel`**
- `AreaAveragingMethod`: **string = `OVER_ANNULUS` | `NONE`**, _Optional_

or

- `$insert`: **string (URI-reference)**

A type of **DynamicWake**

FrozenWakeModel.title: FrozenWakeModel
FrozenWakeModel.description: The frozen wake model keeps the induction velocity from the initial conditions, and doesnâ€™t change the induction either during linearisation perturbations or in the time domain.  In linearisation this lack of response can be a good approximation to the lagged dynamic wake response.  The frozen wake approach is not appropriate in the time domain.
FrozenWakeModel.markdownDescription:
### FrozenWakeModel

_The frozen wake model keeps the induction velocity from the initial conditions, and doesnâ€™t change the induction either during linearisation perturbations or in the time domain.  In linearisation this lack of response can be a good approximation to the lagged dynamic wake response.  The frozen wake approach is not appropriate in the time domain._

- _`DynamicWakeType`_: **string = `FrozenWakeModel`**
- `AreaAveragingMethod`: **string = `OVER_ANNULUS` | `NONE`**, _Optional_

or

- `$insert`: **string (URI-reference)**

A type of **DynamicWake**

DynamicWakeType.description: Defines the specific type of DynamicWake model in use.  For a `FrozenWakeModel` object, this must always be set to a value of `FrozenWakeModel`.
DynamicWakeType.markdownDescription:
DynamicWakeType: **string = `EquilibriumWakeModel` | `FreeFlowModel` | `FrozenWakeModel` | `OyeDynamicWake` | `PittAndPetersModel`**

_Defines the specific type of DynamicWake model in use.  For a `FrozenWakeModel` object, this must always be set to a value of `FrozenWakeModel`._

---

### FrozenWakeModel

_The frozen wake model keeps the induction velocity from the initial conditions, and doesnâ€™t change the induction either during linearisation perturbations or in the time domain.  In linearisation this lack of response can be a good approximation to the lagged dynamic wake response.  The frozen wake approach is not appropriate in the time domain._

- _`DynamicWakeType`_: **string = `FrozenWakeModel`**
- `AreaAveragingMethod`: **string = `OVER_ANNULUS` | `NONE`**, _Optional_

or

- `$insert`: **string (URI-reference)**

A type of **DynamicWake**

OyeDynamicWake.title: OyeDynamicWake
OyeDynamicWake.description: The Oye dynamic wake model captures the lag in induction in response to a change of inflow conditions.  It is the most accurate model for linearisation and time domain, but it does increase linearisation time significantly as it introduces extra states.
OyeDynamicWake.markdownDescription:
### OyeDynamicWake

_The Oye dynamic wake model captures the lag in induction in response to a change of inflow conditions.  It is the most accurate model for linearisation and time domain, but it does increase linearisation time significantly as it introduces extra states._

- _`DynamicWakeType`_: **string = `OyeDynamicWake`**
- `AreaAveragingMethod`: **string = `OVER_ANNULUS` | `NONE`**, _Optional_
- `DynamicTangentialInduction`: **boolean**, _Optional_
- `OyeTimeLagMultiplier`: **number**, _Optional_

or

- `$insert`: **string (URI-reference)**

A type of **DynamicWake**

DynamicWakeType.description: Defines the specific type of DynamicWake model in use.  For a `OyeDynamicWake` object, this must always be set to a value of `OyeDynamicWake`.
DynamicWakeType.markdownDescription:
DynamicWakeType: **string = `EquilibriumWakeModel` | `FreeFlowModel` | `FrozenWakeModel` | `OyeDynamicWake` | `PittAndPetersModel`**

_Defines the specific type of DynamicWake model in use.  For a `OyeDynamicWake` object, this must always be set to a value of `OyeDynamicWake`._

---

### OyeDynamicWake

_The Oye dynamic wake model captures the lag in induction in response to a change of inflow conditions.  It is the most accurate model for linearisation and time domain, but it does increase linearisation time significantly as it introduces extra states._

- _`DynamicWakeType`_: **string = `OyeDynamicWake`**
- `AreaAveragingMethod`: **string = `OVER_ANNULUS` | `NONE`**, _Optional_
- `DynamicTangentialInduction`: **boolean**, _Optional_
- `OyeTimeLagMultiplier`: **number**, _Optional_

or

- `$insert`: **string (URI-reference)**

A type of **DynamicWake**

DynamicTangentialInduction.description: If false, the tangential induction will be solved by iteration on each time step, as per the Pitt and Peters model.
DynamicTangentialInduction.markdownDescription:

_If false, the tangential induction will be solved by iteration on each time step, as per the Pitt and Peters model._

Optional, Default = `true`

OyeTimeLagMultiplier.description: The time constant for the Oye dynamic wake model.
OyeTimeLagMultiplier.markdownDescription:
OyeTimeLagMultiplier: **number**

_The time constant for the Oye dynamic wake model._

Optional, Default = `1.0`

AreaAveragingMethod.description: With the "over annulus" method, the dynamic wake is calculated over the entire annular ring.  Induced velocities are averaged over the number of blades.  If "none" is selected, the annulus is divided into segments to which separate dynamic wakes are applied.
AreaAveragingMethod.markdownDescription:
AreaAveragingMethod: **string = `OVER_ANNULUS` | `NONE`**

SequentialTimestepAdaptation.title: SequentialTimestepAdaptation
SequentialTimestepAdaptation.description: Parameters for the Sequential Timestep Adaptation (STA) technique.
SequentialTimestepAdaptation.markdownDescription:
### SequentialTimestepAdaptation

_**Not supported yet**_

_Parameters for the Sequential Timestep Adaptation (STA) technique._

- ~~`FineTimeStepStart`~~: **number** (s), _Optional_
- ~~`MaximumTimestepCoarseningLevel`~~: **number**, _Optional_

or

- ~~`$insert`~~: **string (URI-reference)**

FineTimeStepStart.description: The time at which the fine time step will start being used.  It is recommended to select a sufficient time buffer to allow wake to develop before evaluating the results.  A value of 0.0 (default) means that the fine time starts right away (no STA technique in use); a value greater than zero means that the STA technique in use.  Consider setting it to be a value such that it starts during the transient initial simulation period.
FineTimeStepStart.markdownDescription:
FineTimeStepStart: **number** (s)

_**Not supported yet**_

_The time at which the fine time step will start being used.  It is recommended to select a sufficient time buffer to allow wake to develop before evaluating the results.  A value of 0.0 (default) means that the fine time starts right away (no STA technique in use); a value greater than zero means that the STA technique in use.  Consider setting it to be a value such that it starts during the transient initial simulation period._

Optional, Default = `0.0`

MaximumTimestepCoarseningLevel.description: The maximum multiplier of the time step for updating vortex wake time step.  A value of 1.0 (default) means the Vortex wake time step is constant (no STA technique in use).  A value greater than 1.0 means the STA technique in use, and the vortex wake time step is multiplied at maximum by this number.
MaximumTimestepCoarseningLevel.markdownDescription:
MaximumTimestepCoarseningLevel: **number**

_**Not supported yet**_

_The maximum multiplier of the time step for updating vortex wake time step.  A value of 1.0 (default) means the Vortex wake time step is constant (no STA technique in use).  A value greater than 1.0 means the STA technique in use, and the vortex wake time step is multiplied at maximum by this number._

Optional, Default = `1.0`

UseKirchoffFlow.description: If true,the normal force coefficient is computed using the dynamic separation position in Kirchoff's equation directly.  If false, the dynamic separation position is used to linearly interpolate between fully separated and fully attached flow. In normal operating conditions this setting will not lead to significant differences, but it has been found that in parked/idling cases (where the blade experiences high angles of attack) this option will improve the aerodynamic damping of the blade. The explanation for the damping differences is given in the aerodynamic validation document on the User Portal.
UseKirchoffFlow.markdownDescription:
UseKirchoffFlow: **boolean**

_If true,the normal force coefficient is computed using the dynamic separation position in Kirchoff's equation directly.  If false, the dynamic separation position is used to linearly interpolate between fully separated and fully attached flow. In normal operating conditions this setting will not lead to significant differences, but it has been found that in parked/idling cases (where the blade experiences high angles of attack) this option will improve the aerodynamic damping of the blade. The explanation for the damping differences is given in the aerodynamic validation document on the User Portal._

Optional, Default = `false`

UseImpulsiveContributions.description: Enabling the impulsive contributions in lift and moment coefficient.

AttachedFlowConstantB2.markdownDescription:

_The constant B2 for the Beddoes-Leishman type dynamic stall model to control the attached flow states._

Optional, Default = `0.3`

UseDynamicPitchingMomentCoefficient.description: If true, the dynamic pitching moment coefficient will be used.  This option is enabled by default.  It is not recommended to disable this option for blades with a torsional degree of freedom because the so-called 'pitch- rate damping' term of the moment coefficient is typically important to keep the blade torsional mode stable.
UseDynamicPitchingMomentCoefficient.markdownDescription:
UseDynamicPitchingMomentCoefficient: **boolean**

_If true, the dynamic pitching moment coefficient will be used.  This option is enabled by default.  It is not recommended to disable this option for blades with a torsional degree of freedom because the so-called 'pitch- rate damping' term of the moment coefficient is typically important to keep the blade torsional mode stable._

Optional, Default = `true`

StartingRadius.description: The fraction of the radius outboard of which the dynamic stall model will be used. A value of 0.0 means that dynamic stall is applied from the blade root.
StartingRadius.markdownDescription:
StartingRadius: **number**

_The fraction of the radius outboard of which the dynamic stall model will be used. A value of 0.0 means that dynamic stall is applied from the blade root._

Optional, Default = `0.0`

EndingRadius.description: The fraction of the radius outboard of which the dynamic stall model will be switched off. A value of 1.0 means that dynamic stall is applied until the blade tip.
EndingRadius.markdownDescription:
EndingRadius: **number**

_The fraction of the radius outboard of which the dynamic stall model will be switched off. A value of 1.0 means that dynamic stall is applied until the blade tip._

Optional, Default = `0.95`

SeparationTimeConstant.description: A dimensionless time constant, given in terms of the time taken to travel half a chord. It defines the lag in the movement of the separation point due to unsteady pressure and boundary layer response.
SeparationTimeConstant.markdownDescription:
SeparationTimeConstant: **number**

_A dimensionless time constant, given in terms of the time taken to travel half a chord. It defines the lag in the movement of the separation point due to unsteady pressure and boundary layer response._

Optional, Default = `3.0`

UseLinearFitGradientMethod.description: If true, the linear fit polar gradient is used to reconstruct the inviscid polar data. The fit is performed only within the linear polar regime that is searched automatically between the zero lift AoA to AoA = 7 deg. This approach is more suitable for polar data sets where the lift coefficient slope is not straight around 0 deg angle of attack. It is recommended to activate this option for more accurate computations. This option is turned on by default.
UseLinearFitGradientMethod.markdownDescription:
UseLinearFitGradientMethod: **boolean**

_If true, the linear fit polar gradient is used to reconstruct the inviscid polar data. The fit is performed only within the linear polar regime that is searched automatically between the zero lift AoA to AoA = 7 deg. This approach is more suitable for polar data sets where the lift coefficient slope is not straight around 0 deg angle of attack. It is recommended to activate this option for more accurate computations. This option is turned on by default._

Optional, Default = `true`

Logging.title: Logging
Logging.description: Default settings for the logging of the supporting data, such as verification or progress data.  Many of these settings can be overridden for individual analyses using command line options.
Logging.markdownDescription:
### Logging

_Default settings for the logging of the supporting data, such as verification or progress data.  Many of these settings can be overridden for individual analyses using command line options._

- `ConsoleLoggingLevel`: **string = `SILENT` | `EXCEPTIONS` | `WARNINGS` | `INFORMATION` | `DIAGNOSTIC`**, _Optional_
- `MessageFileLoggingLevel`: **string = `EXCEPTIONS` | `WARNINGS` | `INFORMATION` | `DIAGNOSTIC`**, _Optional_
- `SupportingFiles`: **string = `BASIC` | `VERIFICATION` | `DIAGNOSTIC`**, _Optional_
- `ProgressFile`: **boolean**, _Optional_
- `Visualisation`: **string = `NONE` | `MODEL` | `ANIMATION`**, _Optional_

or

- `$insert`: **string (URI-reference)**

ConsoleLoggingLevel.description:
The level of detail to report to the calculation console window:
  'SILENT': there will be no messages written to the console.
  'EXCEPTIONS': only error messages will be written to the console.
  'WARNING': error messages plus warning messages.
  'INFORMATION': additional notes describing the simulation.
  'DIAGNOSTIC': includes additional details which would might help explain more subtle simulation behaviour.
ConsoleLoggingLevel.markdownDescription:
ConsoleLoggingLevel: **string = `SILENT` | `EXCEPTIONS` | `WARNINGS` | `INFORMATION` | `DIAGNOSTIC`**

_The level of detail to report to the calculation console window:_

_'SILENT': there will be no messages written to the console._

_'EXCEPTIONS': only error messages will be written to the console._

_'WARNING': error messages plus warning messages._

_'INFORMATION': additional notes describing the simulation._

_'DIAGNOSTIC': includes additional details which would might help explain more subtle simulation behaviour._

Optional, Default = `WARNINGS`

MessageFileLoggingLevel.description:
The level of detail to report to the $ME message file:
  'EXCEPTIONS': only error messages will be written to the file.
  'WARNING': error messages plus warning messages.
  'INFORMATION': additional notes describing the simulation.
  'DIAGNOSTIC': includes additional details which would might help explain more subtle simulation behaviour.
MessageFileLoggingLevel.markdownDescription:
MessageFileLoggingLevel: **string = `EXCEPTIONS` | `WARNINGS` | `INFORMATION` | `DIAGNOSTIC`**

_The level of detail to report to the $ME message file:_

_'EXCEPTIONS': only error messages will be written to the file._

_'WARNING': error messages plus warning messages._

_'INFORMATION': additional notes describing the simulation._

_'DIAGNOSTIC': includes additional details which would might help explain more subtle simulation behaviour._

Optional, Default = `INFORMATION`

SupportingFiles.description:
The level of supporting files to be written to the output directory during the analysis:
  'BASIC' includes .$ME and .$TE files.
  'VERIFICATION' produces additional reports summarising the inputs with minimal processing, such as inertia properties and basic mode data.
  'DIAGNOSTIC' will output any data during the analysis that may assist in diagnosing problems. This may impair the performance.
These options are cumulative, with DIAGNOSTIC including all VERIFICATION outputs; VERIFICATION indluding all CONSOLIDATED_INPUTS; and CONSOLIDATED_INPUTS including all BASIC outputs.
SupportingFiles.markdownDescription:
SupportingFiles: **string = `BASIC` | `VERIFICATION` | `DIAGNOSTIC`**

_The level of supporting files to be written to the output directory during the analysis:_

_'BASIC' includes .$ME and .$TE files._

_'VERIFICATION' produces additional reports summarising the inputs with minimal processing, such as inertia properties and basic mode data._

_'DIAGNOSTIC' will output any data during the analysis that may assist in diagnosing problems. This may impair the performance._

_These options are cumulative, with DIAGNOSTIC including all VERIFICATION outputs; VERIFICATION indluding all CONSOLIDATED\_INPUTS; and CONSOLIDATED\_INPUTS including all BASIC outputs._

Optional, Default = `BASIC`

ProgressFile.description: If true, a .$PR file containing a single number detailing the progree will be written to the working directory and updated throughout the analysis.  This can be read by the calling process such as a GUI or batch manager.
ProgressFile.markdownDescription:
ProgressFile: **boolean**

_If true, a .$PR file containing a single number detailing the progree will be written to the working directory and updated throughout the analysis.  This can be read by the calling process such as a GUI or batch manager._

Optional, Default = `true`

Visualisation.description:
The level of additional visualisation files to produce during an analysis:
  'MODEL' produces additional files to allow external software to produce a static 3D model of the turbine.
  'ANIMATION' produces additional files and time-series to allow external software to animate the movement of the turbine.
Visualisation.markdownDescription:
Visualisation: **string = `NONE` | `MODEL` | `ANIMATION`**

_The level of additional visualisation files to produce during an analysis:_

_'MODEL' produces additional files to allow external software to produce a static 3D model of the turbine._

_'ANIMATION' produces additional files and time-series to allow external software to animate the movement of the turbine._

Optional, Default = `NONE`

MaximumNumberOfIterations.markdownDescription:

_The maximum number of iterations for prescribed freedoms and first order states (e.g. dynamic stall & wake).  A value of 1 may sometimes inprecisely integrate first order states_

Optional, Default = `1`

Beta.description: The β parameter for the Newmark-β integration method.  The recommended value of 0.25 (with a γ value of 0.50) results in the constant average acceleration method that is unconditionally stable for linear systems.  A value of 0.26 (with a γ value of 0.52) results in a method that is close to the constant average acceleration method but includes a small amount of numerical damping to reduce unwanted vibrations of high-frequency modes. Note that the numerical damping increases with the step size.
Beta.markdownDescription:
Beta: **number**

_The β parameter for the Newmark-β integration method.  The recommended value of 0.25 (with a γ value of 0.50) results in the constant average acceleration method that is unconditionally stable for linear systems.  A value of 0.26 (with a γ value of 0.52) results in a method that is close to the constant average acceleration method but includes a small amount of numerical damping to reduce unwanted vibrations of high-frequency modes. Note that the numerical damping increases with the step size._

Optional, Default = `0.25`

Gamma.description: The γ parameter for the Newmark-β integration method.  The recommended value depends on the β parameter and given by the formula γ = 2.sqrt(β) - 0.5.  Values higher than 0.5 introduce positive numerical damping, whereas lower values introduce negative numerical damping.

ToleranceMultiplier.description: The tolerance used for defining the convergence criteria of the Newton-Raphson equilibrium iterations for 1st and 2nd order states.  Reduced values of this parameter result in more iterations and more accurate solutions, whereas increased values result in less iterations and less accurate solutions, which eventually may cause stability problems.  The allowable range of values for this parameter is 0.001 to 1000.

- `MaximumTimeStep`: **number** (s), _Optional_

or

A type of **Integrator**

InitialStep.description: The recommended value is zero: the minimum time step will in fact be used.  A value larger than the minimum time step will speed up the initialisation of the simulation, but there is a risk of numerical problems if too large a value is used.
InitialStep.markdownDescription:
InitialStep: **number** (s)

_The recommended value is zero: the minimum time step will in fact be used.  A value larger than the minimum time step will speed up the initialisation of the simulation, but there is a risk of numerical problems if too large a value is used._

Optional, Default = `0`

Tolerance.description: The tolerance for the variable step integrator: This parameter defines the precision of the simulation. All states are integrated to an error within the integration tolerance multiplied by the state magnitude at that step. A higher value can increase simulation speed but lower precision.  Fixed step integrators: When the "Maximum number of iterations" > 1, the integrator relative tolerance is used to control how many iterations are carried out when integrating the first order and prescribed second order states. Iterations are carried out until the maximum number of iterations is reached, or until the change in all first order and prescribed state derivatives between successive iterations is less than the relative tolerance multiplied by the state derivative absolute value.
Tolerance.markdownDescription:
Tolerance: **number**

_The tolerance for the variable step integrator: This parameter defines the precision of the simulation. All states are integrated to an error within the integration tolerance multiplied by the state magnitude at that step. A higher value can increase simulation speed but lower precision.  Fixed step integrators: When the "Maximum number of iterations" > 1, the integrator relative tolerance is used to control how many iterations are carried out when integrating the first order and prescribed second order states. Iterations are carried out until the maximum number of iterations is reached, or until the change in all first order and prescribed state derivatives between successive iterations is less than the relative tolerance multiplied by the state derivative absolute value._

Optional, Default = `0.005`

MinimumTimeStep.description: The minimum time step.  The simulation uses a 4/5th order Runge-Kutta variable time step method.  The time step will be reduced automatically if the specified tolerance is exceeded, until this minimum value is reached.
MinimumTimeStep.markdownDescription:
MinimumTimeStep: **number** (s)

_The minimum time step.  The simulation uses a 4/5th order Runge-Kutta variable time step method.  The time step will be reduced automatically if the specified tolerance is exceeded, until this minimum value is reached._

Optional, Default = `1e-07`

MaximumTimeStep.description: The maximum time step.  This should normally be the same as the output time step, although a smaller value might be useful in some cases if the output time step is particularly long.  A very small value for the minimum time step is recommended, such as 10^-8 s, to ensure that the accuracy of simulation is not constrained by this.  In special cases, increasing the minimum time step may speed up the simulation with little loss of accuracy, but it is advisable to check that the results are not significantly altered by doing this.  This situation may arise for example with a dynamic mode which is inactive because it is heavily damped.  It may be better to remove the mode completely.
MaximumTimeStep.markdownDescription:
MaximumTimeStep: **number** (s)

_The maximum time step.  This should normally be the same as the output time step, although a smaller value might be useful in some cases if the output time step is particularly long.  A very small value for the minimum time step is recommended, such as 10^-8 s, to ensure that the accuracy of simulation is not constrained by this.  In special cases, increasing the minimum time step may speed up the simulation with little loss of accuracy, but it is advisable to check that the results are not significantly altered by doing this.  This situation may arise for example with a dynamic mode which is inactive because it is heavily damped.  It may be better to remove the mode completely._

Optional, Default = `1.0`

TimeStep.description: The fixed time step used by the integrator.  It must be set as a divisor of the output time-step and external controller communication interval.
TimeStep.markdownDescription:
TimeStep: **number** (s)

_The fixed time step used by the integrator.  It must be set as a divisor of the output time-step and external controller communication interval._

Optional, Default = `0.005`

Tolerance.description: When the "Maximum number of iterations" > 1, the integrator relative tolerance is used to control how many iterations are carried out when integrating the first order and prescribed second order states.  Iterations are carried out until the maximum number of iterations is reached, or until the change in all first order and prescribed state derivatives between successive iterations is less than the relative tolerance multiplied by the state derivative absolute value.
Tolerance.markdownDescription:
Tolerance: **number**

_When the "Maximum number of iterations" > 1, the integrator relative tolerance is used to control how many iterations are carried out when integrating the first order and prescribed second order states.  Iterations are carried out until the maximum number of iterations is reached, or until the change in all first order and prescribed state derivatives between successive iterations is less than the relative tolerance multiplied by the state derivative absolute value._

Optional, Default = `0.005`

_The inclination of the flow relative to the horizontal plane.  Typically this is in the order of 8 degrees for an onshore turbine, and 0 degrees for an offshore turbine._

Optional, Default = `0.0`

CampbellPowerProduction.title: CampbellPowerProduction
CampbellPowerProduction.description: The properties for generating a Campbell diagram for a turbine in power production mode.  This will use the steady-state operating parameters defined in the TurbineOperationalParameters section to determine the operating point for the specified wind speeds.
CampbellPowerProduction.markdownDescription:
### CampbellPowerProduction

_The properties for generating a Campbell diagram for a turbine in power production mode.  This will use the steady-state operating parameters defined in the TurbineOperationalParameters section to determine the operating point for the specified wind speeds._

- _`CampbellDiagramModeOfOperationType`_: **string = `PowerProduction`**
- `WindSpeedRange`: **object (VelocityRange)**

or

- `$insert`: **string (URI-reference)**

A type of **CampbellDiagramModeOfOperation**

CampbellDiagramModeOfOperationType.description: Defines the specific type of CampbellDiagramModeOfOperation model in use.  For a `PowerProduction` object, this must always be set to a value of `PowerProduction`.
CampbellDiagramModeOfOperationType.markdownDescription:
CampbellDiagramModeOfOperationType: **string = `Idling` | `Parked` | `PowerProduction`**

_Defines the specific type of CampbellDiagramModeOfOperation model in use.  For a `PowerProduction` object, this must always be set to a value of `PowerProduction`._

---

### CampbellPowerProduction

_The properties for generating a Campbell diagram for a turbine in power production mode.  This will use the steady-state operating parameters defined in the TurbineOperationalParameters section to determine the operating point for the specified wind speeds._

- _`CampbellDiagramModeOfOperationType`_: **string = `PowerProduction`**
- `WindSpeedRange`: **object (VelocityRange)**

or

- `$insert`: **string (URI-reference)**

A type of **CampbellDiagramModeOfOperation**

Maximum.description: The highest tip speed ratio to consider.

LinearisationAzimuthPositions.title: LinearisationAzimuthPositions
LinearisationAzimuthPositions.description: Settings to control the azimuthal positions used in the analysis. If omitted, a single azimuthal position of zero is used. When more than one azimuthal position is used, the positions for the analysis are calculated such that they are evenly distributed around the circle.
LinearisationAzimuthPositions.markdownDescription:
### LinearisationAzimuthPositions

_Settings to control the azimuthal positions used in the analysis. If omitted, a single azimuthal position of zero is used. When more than one azimuthal position is used, the positions for the analysis are calculated such that they are evenly distributed around the circle._

- `FirstAzimuthPosition`: **number** (rad), _Optional_
- `NumberOfAzimuthPositions`: **integer**, _Optional_

or

- `$insert`: **string (URI-reference)**

FirstAzimuthPosition.description: The first azimuthal position (in radians) used in the analysis. If the NumberOfAzimuthPositions = 1, then this is the only azimuthal position.
FirstAzimuthPosition.markdownDescription:
FirstAzimuthPosition: **number** (rad)

_The first azimuthal position (in radians) used in the analysis. If the NumberOfAzimuthPositions = 1, then this is the only azimuthal position._

Optional, Default = `0.0`

NumberOfAzimuthPositions.description: The number of azimuthal positions. Azimuthal positions for the analysis will be calculated such that they are evenly distributed around the whole circle.
NumberOfAzimuthPositions.markdownDescription:
NumberOfAzimuthPositions: **integer**

_The number of azimuthal positions. Azimuthal positions for the analysis will be calculated such that they are evenly distributed around the whole circle._

Optional, Default = `1`

ModelLinearisation.title: ModelLinearisation
ModelLinearisation.description: Defines a calculation which produces a linear model.  This can be post-processed into a linearised model of the turbine in state-space form.  This is of particular value in the design of controllers.
ModelLinearisation.markdownDescription:
### ModelLinearisation

_Defines a calculation which produces a linear model.  This can be post-processed into a linearised model of the turbine in state-space form.  This is of particular value in the design of controllers._

- _`SteadyCalculationType`_: **string = `ModelLinearisation`**
- `Outputs`: **object (SteadyCalculationOutputs)**
- `TransformRotorModesToNonRotating`: **boolean**, _Optional_
- `AlignWindFieldWithDeflectedHubAxis`: **boolean**, _Optional_
- `EvenlySpacedAzimuthPositions`: **object (LinearisationAzimuthPositions)**, _Optional_
- `WindSpeedRange`: **object (VelocityRange)**
- `Perturbations`: **object (ModelLinearisationPerturbations)**, _Optional_

or

- `$insert`: **string (URI-reference)**

A type of **SteadyCalculation**

SteadyCalculationType.description: Defines the specific type of SteadyCalculation model in use.  For a `ModelLinearisation` object, this must always be set to a value of `ModelLinearisation`.
SteadyCalculationType.markdownDescription:
SteadyCalculationType: **string = `AerodynamicInformation` | `CampbellDiagram` | `ModalAnalysis` | `ModelLinearisation` | `PerformanceCoefficients` | `SteadyOperationalLoads` | `SteadyParkedLoads` | `SteadyPowerCurve`**

_Defines the specific type of SteadyCalculation model in use.  For a `ModelLinearisation` object, this must always be set to a value of `ModelLinearisation`._

---

### ModelLinearisation

_Defines a calculation which produces a linear model.  This can be post-processed into a linearised model of the turbine in state-space form.  This is of particular value in the design of controllers._

- _`SteadyCalculationType`_: **string = `ModelLinearisation`**
- `Outputs`: **object (SteadyCalculationOutputs)**
- `TransformRotorModesToNonRotating`: **boolean**, _Optional_
- `AlignWindFieldWithDeflectedHubAxis`: **boolean**, _Optional_
- `EvenlySpacedAzimuthPositions`: **object (LinearisationAzimuthPositions)**, _Optional_
- `WindSpeedRange`: **object (VelocityRange)**
- `Perturbations`: **object (ModelLinearisationPerturbations)**, _Optional_

or

- `$insert`: **string (URI-reference)**

A type of **SteadyCalculation**

WindSpeedRange.description: The range of wind speeds to consider.
WindSpeedRange.markdownDescription:
WindSpeedRange: **object (VelocityRange)**

_The range of wind speeds to consider._

Perturbations.description: The perturbations to apply during the linearisation calculations.
Perturbations.markdownDescription:
Perturbations: **object (ModelLinearisationPerturbations)**

_The perturbations to apply during the linearisation calculations._

Optional

WindSpeedPerturbation.description: The magnitude of perturbation of the wind speed around the equilibrium value.  It should be small so that the analysis stays in the linear region  Omit keyword in order to let Bladed calculate a default perturbation.
WindSpeedPerturbation.markdownDescription:
WindSpeedPerturbation: **number** (m/s)

_The magnitude of perturbation of the wind speed around the equilibrium value.  It should be small so that the analysis stays in the linear region  Omit keyword in order to let Bladed calculate a default perturbation._

Optional, Default = `0.1`

PitchDemandPerturbation.description: The magnitude of perturbation of the pitch angle or rate demand around the equilibrium value.  It should be small so that the analysis stays in the linear region.  The default value will be interpreted as an angle in the case of a position demand, and an angular velocity in the case of a rate demand.
PitchDemandPerturbation.markdownDescription:
PitchDemandPerturbation: **number**

_The magnitude of perturbation of the pitch angle or rate demand around the equilibrium value.  It should be small so that the analysis stays in the linear region.  The default value will be interpreted as an angle in the case of a position demand, and an angular velocity in the case of a rate demand._

Optional, Default = `0.0001`

PitchActuationPerturbation.description: The magnitude of perturbation of the pitch actuation force or torque around the equilibrium value.  It should be small so that the analysis stays in the linear region.  If omitted, the pitch demand will be perturbed instead.
PitchActuationPerturbation.markdownDescription:
PitchActuationPerturbation: **number**

_The magnitude of perturbation of the pitch actuation force or torque around the equilibrium value.  It should be small so that the analysis stays in the linear region.  If omitted, the pitch demand will be perturbed instead._

Optional

GeneratorTorqueDemandPerturbation.description: The magnitude of perturbation of the generator torque demand around the equilibrium value.  It should be small so that the analysis stays in the linear region.
GeneratorTorqueDemandPerturbation.markdownDescription:
GeneratorTorqueDemandPerturbation: **number** (Nm)

_The magnitude of perturbation of the generator torque demand around the equilibrium value.  It should be small so that the analysis stays in the linear region._

Optional, Default = `1000.0`

WindShearPerturbation.description: The magnitude of both horizontal and vertical shear perturbations. The wind shear is perturbued by linearly varying the wind speed in proportion to to vertical or horizontal distance from the rotor centre.  If omitted, the wind shears will not be perturbed as part of this analysis.
WindShearPerturbation.markdownDescription:
WindShearPerturbation: **number** (Hz)

_The magnitude of both horizontal and vertical shear perturbations. The wind shear is perturbued by linearly varying the wind speed in proportion to to vertical or horizontal distance from the rotor centre.  If omitted, the wind shears will not be perturbed as part of this analysis._

Optional

YawActuatorTorquePerturbation.description: Yaw actuator torque perturbation. The torque perturbation is evenly distributed across the actuator banks.  If omitted, the yaw torque will not be perturbed as part of this analysis.
YawActuatorTorquePerturbation.markdownDescription:
YawActuatorTorquePerturbation: **number** (Nm)

_**Not supported yet**_

_Yaw actuator torque perturbation. The torque perturbation is evenly distributed across the actuator banks.  If omitted, the yaw torque will not be perturbed as part of this analysis._

Optional

ModelLinearisationPerturbations.title: ModelLinearisationPerturbations
ModelLinearisationPerturbations.description: Settings to control the number of perturbations and the perturbation magnitudes.

_Settings to control the number of perturbations and the perturbation magnitudes._

- `NumberOfPerturbationPoints`: **integer**, _Optional_
- `AbsoluteTolerancePerturbationMultiplier`: **number**, _Optional_
- `StateRelativePerturbation`: **number**, _Optional_
- `ApplyPitchPerturbationToEachBlade`: **boolean**, _Optional_
- `PerturbationMagnitudes`: **object (ModelLinearisationPerturbationMagnitudes)**, _Optional_

or

ApplyPitchPerturbationToEachBlade.description: If true, the pitch angle will be perturbed in turn for each blade as well as collectively for all blades
ApplyPitchPerturbationToEachBlade.markdownDescription:
ApplyPitchPerturbationToEachBlade: **boolean**

_If true, the pitch angle will be perturbed in turn for each blade as well as collectively for all blades_

Optional, Default = `false`

PerturbationMagnitudes.description: Set the perturbations magnitudes for certain states and inputs to the linearisation
PerturbationMagnitudes.markdownDescription:
PerturbationMagnitudes: **object (ModelLinearisationPerturbationMagnitudes)**

_Set the perturbations magnitudes for certain states and inputs to the linearisation_

Optional, Default = `False`

PerformanceCoefficientsCalculation.title: PerformanceCoefficientsCalculation
PerformanceCoefficientsCalculation.description: Defines a calculation which produces power, torque and thrust coefficients are calculated in a uniform steady wind field.  The rotor is modelled with flexibility as well as prebend and sweep.  However, the rotor is analysed in isolation without any influence from the rest of the turbine structure.
PerformanceCoefficientsCalculation.markdownDescription:
### PerformanceCoefficientsCalculation

_Defines a calculation which produces power, torque and thrust coefficients are calculated in a uniform steady wind field.  The rotor is modelled with flexibility as well as prebend and sweep.  However, the rotor is analysed in isolation without any influence from the rest of the turbine structure._

- _`SteadyCalculationType`_: **string = `PerformanceCoefficients`**
- `TipSpeedRatioRange`: **object (DimensionlessRange)**
- `PitchRange`: **object (AngleRange)**
- `RotorSpeed`: **number** (rad/s)
- `Outputs`: **object (SteadyCalculationOutputs)**

or

- `$insert`: **string (URI-reference)**

A type of **SteadyCalculation**

SteadyCalculationType.description: Defines the specific type of SteadyCalculation model in use.  For a `PerformanceCoefficients` object, this must always be set to a value of `PerformanceCoefficients`.
SteadyCalculationType.markdownDescription:
SteadyCalculationType: **string = `AerodynamicInformation` | `CampbellDiagram` | `ModalAnalysis` | `ModelLinearisation` | `PerformanceCoefficients` | `SteadyOperationalLoads` | `SteadyParkedLoads` | `SteadyPowerCurve`**

_Defines the specific type of SteadyCalculation model in use.  For a `PerformanceCoefficients` object, this must always be set to a value of `PerformanceCoefficients`._

---

### PerformanceCoefficientsCalculation

_Defines a calculation which produces power, torque and thrust coefficients are calculated in a uniform steady wind field.  The rotor is modelled with flexibility as well as prebend and sweep.  However, the rotor is analysed in isolation without any influence from the rest of the turbine structure._

- _`SteadyCalculationType`_: **string = `PerformanceCoefficients`**
- `TipSpeedRatioRange`: **object (DimensionlessRange)**
- `PitchRange`: **object (AngleRange)**
- `RotorSpeed`: **number** (rad/s)
- `Outputs`: **object (SteadyCalculationOutputs)**

or

SteadyOperationalLoadsCalculation.title: SteadyOperationalLoadsCalculation
SteadyOperationalLoadsCalculation.description: Defines a calculation which produces all the loads in a steady, uniform wind field.  The entire turbine is modelled for this analysis and prebend and sweep included, as well as flexibility.  Most realities such as tower shadow and wind shear are ignored.
SteadyOperationalLoadsCalculation.markdownDescription:
### SteadyOperationalLoadsCalculation

_Defines a calculation which produces all the loads in a steady, uniform wind field.  The entire turbine is modelled for this analysis and prebend and sweep included, as well as flexibility.  Most realities such as tower shadow and wind shear are ignored._

- _`SteadyCalculationType`_: **string = `SteadyOperationalLoads`**
- `WindSpeedRange`: **object (VelocityRange)**
- `Outputs`: **object (SteadyCalculationWithComponentOutputs)**

or

- `$insert`: **string (URI-reference)**

SteadyCalculationType: **string = `AerodynamicInformation` | `CampbellDiagram` | `ModalAnalysis` | `ModelLinearisation` | `PerformanceCoefficients` | `SteadyOperationalLoads` | `SteadyParkedLoads` | `SteadyPowerCurve`**

SteadyParkedLoadsCalculation.title: SteadyParkedLoadsCalculation
SteadyParkedLoadsCalculation.description: Defines a calculation which produces loads on the parked turbine in a steady wind.  Most realities such as tower shadow and wind shear are included, making the calculation almost equivalent to a time domain simulation in a steady wind.
SteadyParkedLoadsCalculation.markdownDescription:
### SteadyParkedLoadsCalculation

_**Not supported yet**_

_Defines a calculation which produces loads on the parked turbine in a steady wind.  Most realities such as tower shadow and wind shear are included, making the calculation almost equivalent to a time domain simulation in a steady wind._

- ~~`WindSpeed`~~: **number** (m/s)

- ~~`FlowInclination`~~: **number** (rad), _Optional_
- ~~`ReferenceHeight`~~: **number** (m), _Optional_
- ~~`WindShear`~~: **object (a type of WindShear)**, _Optional_
- ~~`PitchAngle`~~: **number** (rad), _Optional_
- ~~`SweepParameter`~~: **string = `AZIMUTH_ANGLE` | `YAW_ANGLE` | `FLOW_INCLINATION` | `PITCH_ANGLE`**
- ~~`SweepEnd`~~: **number**
- ~~`SweepInterval`~~: **number**
- ~~`Outputs`~~: **object (SteadyCalculationWithComponentOutputs)**

or

- ~~`$insert`~~: **string (URI-reference)**

_The pitch angle of all of the turbine blades to be considered for the calculation._

RotorSpeed.description: The rotor speed to be considered for the calculation.
RotorSpeed.markdownDescription:
RotorSpeed: **number** (rad/s)

_**Not supported yet**_

_The rotor speed to be considered for the calculation._

TransformRotorModesToNonRotating.description: If true, a multi-blade coordinate (MBC) transform will be performed to transform the rotating modes into the stationary frame of reference.  This will generate forward and backward whirling modes in a Campbell diagram.
TransformRotorModesToNonRotating.markdownDescription:
TransformRotorModesToNonRotating: **boolean**

_If true, a multi-blade coordinate (MBC) transform will be performed to transform the rotating modes into the stationary frame of reference.  This will generate forward and backward whirling modes in a Campbell diagram._

Optional, Default = `true`

AlignWindFieldWithDeflectedHubAxis.description: If true, the deflected steady-state operating conditions of the turbine are calculated, and then the wind field is rotated to align with the rotating axis of the (first) hub for linearisation.
AlignWindFieldWithDeflectedHubAxis.markdownDescription:
AlignWindFieldWithDeflectedHubAxis: **boolean**

_If true, the deflected steady-state operating conditions of the turbine are calculated, and then the wind field is rotated to align with the rotating axis of the (first) hub for linearisation._

Optional, Default = `true`

EvenlySpacedAzimuthPositions.description: Settings to control the azimuthal positions used in the analysis. If omitted, a single azimuthal position of zero is used. When more than one azimuthal position is used, the positions for the analysis are calculated such that they are evenly distributed around the circle.
EvenlySpacedAzimuthPositions.markdownDescription:
EvenlySpacedAzimuthPositions: **object (LinearisationAzimuthPositions)**

_Settings to control the azimuthal positions used in the analysis. If omitted, a single azimuthal position of zero is used. When more than one azimuthal position is used, the positions for the analysis are calculated such that they are evenly distributed around the circle._

Optional

NumberOfPerturbationPoints.description: The number of values that each state gets perturbed to either side of the equilibrium point.  Larger numbers provide more robustness; smaller numbers provide faster analysis and lower memory usage.
NumberOfPerturbationPoints.markdownDescription:
NumberOfPerturbationPoints: **integer**

_The number of values that each state gets perturbed to either side of the equilibrium point.  Larger numbers provide more robustness; smaller numbers provide faster analysis and lower memory usage._

Optional, Default = `3`

AbsoluteTolerancePerturbationMultiplier.description: A state with an equilibrium value close to zero will be perturbed by the absolute state tolerance scaled by this multiplier.
AbsoluteTolerancePerturbationMultiplier.markdownDescription:
AbsoluteTolerancePerturbationMultiplier: **number**

_A state with an equilibrium value close to zero will be perturbed by the absolute state tolerance scaled by this multiplier._

Optional, Default = `1`

StateRelativePerturbation.description: The magnitude of the state perturbations relative to the absolute steady-state state values
StateRelativePerturbation.markdownDescription:
StateRelativePerturbation: **number**

_The magnitude of the state perturbations relative to the absolute steady-state state values_

Optional, Default = `0.005`

VelocityRange.title: VelocityRange
VelocityRange.description: The range of wind speeds to consider.
VelocityRange.markdownDescription:
### VelocityRange

_The range of wind speeds to consider._

- `Minimum`: **number** (m/s)
- `Maximum`: **number** (m/s)
- `Interval`: **number** (m/s)

or

- `$insert`: **string (URI-reference)**

Minimum.description: The lowest wind speed to consider.
Minimum.markdownDescription:
Minimum: **number** (m/s)

_The lowest wind speed to consider._

Maximum.description: The highest wind speed to consider.
Maximum.markdownDescription:
Maximum: **number** (m/s)

_The highest wind speed to consider._

Interval.description: The step size to take from the lowest to the highest wind speed.
Interval.markdownDescription:
Interval: **number** (m/s)

_The step size to take from the lowest to the highest wind speed._

LoadingFilepath.description: A filepath or URI containing one or six degree of loading data.  In the case of the six degrees of freedom, these will be applied in the component's coordinate system.  Where a single degree of freedom is provided, SingleDirectionLoading must also be specified.
LoadingFilepath.markdownDescription:
LoadingFilepath: **string (URI-reference)**

_**Not supported yet**_

i.e. `Assembly.<name1>.<name2>`

- ~~`TimeVsDirectionShear`~~: **array[object (TimeVsCurrentDirectionShear)]**

or

- ~~`$insert`~~: **string (URI-reference)**

A type of **DirectionShearVariation**

DirectionShearVariationType.markdownDescription:
DirectionShearVariationType: **string = `PresetTransient` | `TimeHistory`**

_**Not supported yet**_

or

A type of **DirectionShearVariation**

TimeVsDirectionShear.description: A list of points specifying the wind veer at the corresponding time.  The wind veer will be interpolated between these points; the wind veer before the first point will be constant at the first point's value; and the wind veer after the last point will remain constant at the last point's value

CentreTurbulenceFileOn.description: The method used to position the data in the turbulence file relative to the turbine.  If any part of the rotor exceeds this box, the simulation will terminate with an exception.
CentreTurbulenceFileOn.markdownDescription:
CentreTurbulenceFileOn: **string = `CENTRED_ON_HUB` | `BEST_FIT`**

_**Not supported yet**_

_The method used to position the data in the turbulence file relative to the turbine.  If any part of the rotor exceeds this box, the simulation will terminate with an exception._

Optional

CentreTurbulenceFileAtHeight.description: The height at which to centre the data in the turbulence file.  If any part of the rotor exceeds this box, the simulation will terminate with an exception.
CentreTurbulenceFileAtHeight.markdownDescription:
CentreTurbulenceFileAtHeight: **number** (m)

_**Not supported yet**_

_The height at which to centre the data in the turbulence file.  If any part of the rotor exceeds this box, the simulation will terminate with an exception._

Optional

RepeatTurbulenceFile.description: If true, the turbulence file will be "looped".  If false, the turbulence will be 0 in all three components once the end of the file has been reached.  Using part of a turbulence file may invalidate its turbulence statistics, and no effort is made by Bladed to ensure coherence at the point when it transitions from the end of the wind file back to the beginning.
RepeatTurbulenceFile.markdownDescription:
RepeatTurbulenceFile: **boolean**

_**Not supported yet**_

_If true, the turbulence file will be "looped".  If false, the turbulence will be 0 in all three components once the end of the file has been reached.  Using part of a turbulence file may invalidate its turbulence statistics, and no effort is made by Bladed to ensure coherence at the point when it transitions from the end of the wind file back to the beginning._

Optional

TurbulenceFileStartTime.description: The time into turbulent wind file at start of simulation.  This can be used to synchronise the wind file with simulation.
TurbulenceFileStartTime.markdownDescription:

_**Not supported yet**_

UseTotalAcceleration.description: If true, total acceleration (convective and time derivative) will be used for Morison loading when using the stream function.  The water particle accelerations in Bladed only include the time derivative terms. The convective terms of the water particles can be added when using the stream function for the water particle acceleration calculations.  If irregular waves and additional constrained waves are applied, where the constrained wave is defined by a stream function and total acceleration is turned on, the water particle acceleration will be calculated using local derivatives for the irregular waves and substantive derivatives for the constrained waves and will therefore be inconsistent.
UseTotalAcceleration.markdownDescription:
UseTotalAcceleration: **boolean**

_**Not supported yet**_

_If true, total acceleration (convective and time derivative) will be used for Morison loading when using the stream function.  The water particle accelerations in Bladed only include the time derivative terms. The convective terms of the water particles can be added when using the stream function for the water particle acceleration calculations.  If irregular waves and additional constrained waves are applied, where the constrained wave is defined by a stream function and total acceleration is turned on, the water particle acceleration will be calculated using local derivatives for the irregular waves and substantive derivatives for the constrained waves and will therefore be inconsistent._

Optional

EvolvingTurbulenceExponential.title: EvolvingTurbulenceExponential
EvolvingTurbulenceExponential.description: The settings for Exponential evolving turbulence.  In the case of a normal turbulent wind field, the turbulence is "frozen" and approaches the turbine at a constant block.  Although this doesn't match physical reality, it is a particular problem for Lidar - as it gives them a "perfect" insight into the oncoming wind field.  In order to represent the nature of real turbulence, a second turbulence file is superimposed on the windfield so that it "evolves" as it moves forward.  This is computationally expensive, and is usually applied only to the Lidar readings - although it can be applied to all the wind values in a simulation.
EvolvingTurbulenceExponential.markdownDescription:
### EvolvingTurbulenceExponential

_The settings for Exponential evolving turbulence.  In the case of a normal turbulent wind field, the turbulence is "frozen" and approaches the turbine at a constant block.  Although this doesn't match physical reality, it is a particular problem for Lidar - as it gives them a "perfect" insight into the oncoming wind field.  In order to represent the nature of real turbulence, a second turbulence file is superimposed on the windfield so that it "evolves" as it moves forward.  This is computationally expensive, and is usually applied only to the Lidar readings - although it can be applied to all the wind values in a simulation._

- _`EvolvingTurbulenceType`_: **string = `EvolvingTurbulenceExponential`**
- `SecondTurbulenceFilepath`: **string (URI-reference)**
- `ExponentialFactor`: **number**

or

- `$insert`: **string (URI-reference)**

A type of **EvolvingTurbulence**

EvolvingTurbulenceType.description: Defines the specific type of EvolvingTurbulence model in use.  For a `EvolvingTurbulenceExponential` object, this must always be set to a value of `EvolvingTurbulenceExponential`.
EvolvingTurbulenceType.markdownDescription:
EvolvingTurbulenceType: **string = `EvolvingTurbulenceExponential` | `EvolvingTurbulenceKristensen`**

_Defines the specific type of EvolvingTurbulence model in use.  For a `EvolvingTurbulenceExponential` object, this must always be set to a value of `EvolvingTurbulenceExponential`._

---

In order to represent the nature of real turbulence, a second turbulence file is superimposed on the windfield so that it "evolves" as it moves forward.  This is computationally expensive, and is usually applied only to the Lidar readings - although it can be applied to all the wind values in a simulation._

Gaussian.title: Gaussian
Gaussian.description: A simple model for the reduced velocity of the wind behind another turbine.  This deficit will be applied across a certain region, and this region will not move around during the simulation.  The velocity deficit profile will be based on a Gaussian distribution, scaled by a maximum deficit and the radius of the region affected.
Gaussian.markdownDescription:
### Gaussian

_A simple model for the reduced velocity of the wind behind another turbine.  This deficit will be applied across a certain region, and this region will not move around during the simulation.  The velocity deficit profile will be based on a Gaussian distribution, scaled by a maximum deficit and the radius of the region affected._

- _`SteadyWakeDeficitType`_: **string = `Gaussian`**
- `HorizontalOffsetFromHub`: **number** (m)
- `VerticalOffsetFromHub`: **number** (m)
- `CentrelineVelocityDeficit`: **number**
- `WidthOfDeficit`: **number**

or

- `$insert`: **string (URI-reference)**

A type of **SteadyWakeDeficit**

SteadyWakeDeficitType.description: Defines the specific type of SteadyWakeDeficit model in use.  For a `Gaussian` object, this must always be set to a value of `Gaussian`.
SteadyWakeDeficitType.markdownDescription:
SteadyWakeDeficitType: **string = `Gaussian` | `UserDefined`**

_Defines the specific type of SteadyWakeDeficit model in use.  For a `Gaussian` object, this must always be set to a value of `Gaussian`._

---

### Gaussian

_A simple model for the reduced velocity of the wind behind another turbine.  This deficit will be applied across a certain region, and this region will not move around during the simulation.  The velocity deficit profile will be based on a Gaussian distribution, scaled by a maximum deficit and the radius of the region affected._

- _`SteadyWakeDeficitType`_: **string = `Gaussian`**
- `HorizontalOffsetFromHub`: **number** (m)
- `VerticalOffsetFromHub`: **number** (m)
- `CentrelineVelocityDeficit`: **number**
- `WidthOfDeficit`: **number**

or

A type of **SteadyWakeDeficit**

CentrelineVelocityDeficit.description: The maximum deficit within the affected region, occurring in the centre.  1.0 or 100% would be a reduction of the wind to zero, whereas 0.0 or 0% would represent no change in the free-field wind speed.
CentrelineVelocityDeficit.markdownDescription:
CentrelineVelocityDeficit: **number**

_The maximum deficit within the affected region, occurring in the centre.  1.0 or 100% would be a reduction of the wind to zero, whereas 0.0 or 0% would represent no change in the free-field wind speed._

WidthOfDeficit.description: The width of the region within which there is a velocity deficit.

RadiusVsDeficit.title: RadiusVsDeficit

UserDefinedWakeDeficit.title: UserDefinedWakeDeficit
UserDefinedWakeDeficit.description: A simple model for the reduced velocity of the wind behind another turbine.  This deficit will be applied across a certain region, and this region will not move around during the simulation.  The velocity deficit profile is a look-up table of the radius against the deficit at that radius.
UserDefinedWakeDeficit.markdownDescription:
### UserDefinedWakeDeficit

_A simple model for the reduced velocity of the wind behind another turbine.  This deficit will be applied across a certain region, and this region will not move around during the simulation.  The velocity deficit profile is a look-up table of the radius against the deficit at that radius._

- _`SteadyWakeDeficitType`_: **string = `UserDefined`**
- `HorizontalOffsetFromHub`: **number** (m)
- `VerticalOffsetFromHub`: **number** (m)
- `RadiusVsDeficit`: **array[object (RadiusVsDeficit)]**

or

- `$insert`: **string (URI-reference)**

A type of **SteadyWakeDeficit**

SteadyWakeDeficitType.description: Defines the specific type of SteadyWakeDeficit model in use.  For a `UserDefined` object, this must always be set to a value of `UserDefined`.
SteadyWakeDeficitType.markdownDescription:
SteadyWakeDeficitType: **string = `Gaussian` | `UserDefined`**

_Defines the specific type of SteadyWakeDeficit model in use.  For a `UserDefined` object, this must always be set to a value of `UserDefined`._

---

### UserDefinedWakeDeficit

_A simple model for the reduced velocity of the wind behind another turbine.  This deficit will be applied across a certain region, and this region will not move around during the simulation.  The velocity deficit profile is a look-up table of the radius against the deficit at that radius._

- _`SteadyWakeDeficitType`_: **string = `UserDefined`**
- `HorizontalOffsetFromHub`: **number** (m)
- `VerticalOffsetFromHub`: **number** (m)
- `RadiusVsDeficit`: **array[object (RadiusVsDeficit)]**

or

- `$insert`: **string (URI-reference)**

A type of **SteadyWakeDeficit**

RadiusVsDeficit.description: A list of radii vs the deficit at that radius.  The first value should be at a radius of 0.0, and the largest radius will be the extent of the affected region.  At this point, the deficit is usually 0.0.
RadiusVsDeficit.markdownDescription:
RadiusVsDeficit: **array[object (RadiusVsDeficit)]**

_A list of radii vs the deficit at that radius.  The first value should be at a radius of 0.0, and the largest radius will be the extent of the affected region.  At this point, the deficit is usually 0.0._

TurbulentWind.title: TurbulentWind
TurbulentWind.description: The definition of a turbulent flow field, with the values for the turbulence defined in an external file.
TurbulentWind.markdownDescription:
### TurbulentWind

_The definition of a turbulent flow field, with the values for the turbulence defined in an external file._

- _`WindType`_: **string = `TurbulentWind`**
- `ReferenceHeight`: **number** (m), _Optional_
- `WindShear`: **object (a type of WindShear)**, _Optional_
- `Inclination`: **number** (rad), _Optional_
- `Direction`: **number** (rad), _Optional_
- `DirectionVariation`: **object (a type of WindDirectionVariation)**, _Optional_
- `SteadyWakeDeficit`: **object (a type of SteadyWakeDeficit)**, _Optional_
- `DynamicUpstreamWake`: **object (DynamicUpstreamWake)**, _Optional_
- `MeanSpeed`: **number** (m/s)
- `TurbulenceFilepath`: **string (URI-reference)**
- `TurbulenceIntensity`: **number**
- `TurbulenceIntensityLateral`: **number**
- `TurbulenceIntensityVertical`: **number**
- `CentreTurbulenceFileOn`: **string = `CENTRED_ON_HUB` | `BEST_FIT`**, _Optional_
- `CentreTurbulenceFileAtHeight`: **number** (m), _Optional_
- `InterpolationMethod`: **string = `LINEAR` | `CUBIC_IN_ROTOR_PLANE` | `ALL_CUBIC`**, _Optional_
- `EvolvingTurbulence`: **object (a type of EvolvingTurbulence)**, _Optional_
- `TurbulenceFileStartTime`: **number** (s), _Optional_
- `DirectionShear`: **number** (rad/m), _Optional_

or

- `$insert`: **string (URI-reference)**

A type of **Wind**

WindType.description: Defines the specific type of Wind model in use.  For a `TurbulentWind` object, this must always be set to a value of `TurbulentWind`.
WindType.markdownDescription:
WindType: **string = `ExternalFlowSourceForWind` | `LaminarFlow` | `TurbulentWind`**

_Defines the specific type of Wind model in use.  For a `TurbulentWind` object, this must always be set to a value of `TurbulentWind`._

---

### TurbulentWind

- `CentreTurbulenceFileAtHeight`: **number** (m), _Optional_
- `InterpolationMethod`: **string = `LINEAR` | `CUBIC_IN_ROTOR_PLANE` | `ALL_CUBIC`**, _Optional_

or
